unnormalised: I recently went to D-Mart to stock up on groceries for the month, and let me tell you, the price differences compared to my local kirana store are quite something! I ended up buying around 20 kgs of rice, 5 kgs of atta, and a whole bunch of dals, spices, and other household items. The total bill came to around Rs. 6500, which is easily Rs. 1000 less than what I'd normally pay at the corner store for the same things.
normalised: I recently went to D-Mart to stock up on groceries for the month, and let me tell you, the price differences compared to my local kirana store are quite something! I ended up buying around twenty kilograms of rice, five kilograms of atta, and a whole bunch of dals, spices, and other household items. The total bill came to around rupees six thousand five hundred, which is easily rupees one thousand less than what I'd normally pay at the corner store for the same things.

unnormalised: It's not just the bulk discounts either. Even individual items are priced competitively. For example, I noticed a 1 litre bottle of sunflower oil was going for Rs. 140, while it's usually around Rs. 160-170 elsewhere. Same with things like sugar – a 5 kg bag was marked at Rs. 220. The deals are pretty tempting if you're willing to brave the crowds, especially on weekends. Last Sunday, it took me almost 45 mins just to check out!
normalised: It's not just the bulk discounts either. Even individual items are priced competitively. For example, I noticed a one liter bottle of sunflower oil was going for rupees one hundred and forty, while it's usually around rupees one hundred and sixty to one hundred and seventy elsewhere. Same with things like sugar – a five kilogram bag was marked at rupees two hundred and twenty. The deals are pretty tempting if you're willing to brave the crowds, especially on weekends. Last Sunday, it took me almost forty five minutes just to check out!

unnormalised: Online shopping's also a big thing now. Sites like Amazon and Flipkart often have flash sales. I bought a new microwave oven for Rs. 5000 during Diwali sale, which originally was priced at Rs. 7000. My brother uses JioMart extensively, he says their prices on vegetables and fruits are unbeatable at times, sometimes you get a kg of tomatoes for just Rs. 10, but that's rare.
normalised: Online shopping's also a big thing now. Sites like Amazon and Flipkart often have flash sales. I bought a new microwave oven for rupees five thousand during Diwali sale, which originally was priced at rupees seven thousand. My brother uses JioMart extensively, he says their prices on vegetables and fruits are unbeatable at times, sometimes you get a one kilogram of tomatoes for just rupees ten, but that's rare.

unnormalised: Ultimately, it's a trade-off, right? Convenience vs. cost savings. I still prefer going to my local store for quick, small purchases. For the big monthly haul, though, the savings at D-Mart or online retailers are too significant to ignore, especially when you are on a budget.
normalised: Ultimately, it's a trade-off, right? Convenience versus cost savings. I still prefer going to my local store for quick, small purchases. For the big monthly haul, though, the savings at D-Mart or online retailers are too significant to ignore, especially when you are on a budget.
